article_title: Milltown residents urged to report suspicious activity
article_text:
Buy Photo Police blotter items from Middlesex County. (Photo: File photo )Buy Photo

MIDDLESEX BOROUGH

THEFT, 8:23 a.m. Oct. 17. A resident of the 400 block of Lincoln Boulevard reported the theft of prescription medication from her unlocked and unattended vehicle. The value of the medication was reported as $30. Officer Paul Steffanelli investigated.

DRUG ARREST, 9:25 p.m. Oct. 18. Dina Wahib Abdalla, 25, of Piscataway, was arrested and charged with possession of marijuana following a motor vehicle stop on William Street at Mountain Avenue. Abdalla was released on her own recognizance. Officer Scott Christofides investigated.

DRUG ARREST, 10 p.m. Oct. 20. Fredy Gochez, 24, of Middlesex, was arrested and charged with possession of marijuana and possession of drug paraphernalia. Officer George Pilesky was investigating a suspicious vehicle in the parking lot of the Hamiltonian Apartments and discovered Gochez in possession of a plastic bag containing marijuana and a grinder. Gochez was released on his own recognizance.

THEFT, 1:52 p.m. Oct. 21. A resident of the 100 block of Fairview Avenue reported the theft of a vehicle exhaust pipe, a catalytic converter and two oxygen sensors from his property. The value of the items taken was reported to be $300. Officer James Morley investigated.

DRUG PARAPHERNALIA ARREST, 3:13 p.m. Oct. 21. Vincent J. Cucchiaro, 24, of Middlesex, was arrested and charged with possession of drug paraphernalia. Officer Emmanuel Malasig was investigating a motor vehicle crash on Harris Avenue at Union Avenue when he determined that there was an arrest warrant for Cucchiaro. Subsequent to his arrest, Cucchiaro was found to be in possession of six wax paper folds that were believed to have contained heroin. He was remanded to the Middlesex County Adult Corrections Center in North Brunswick on $5,000 bail.

UNLAWFUL POSSESSION, 4:03 p.m. Oct. 24. Robert F. Billiard, 33, of Green Brook, was arrested and charged with unlawful possession of a handgun. Officers Chad Corner and Richard Szymczak discovered a loaded, .45 caliber, semiautomatic handgun in the waistband of Billiard’s pants when they escorted him from his vehicle, which was being impounded for displaying fictitious registration plates. Billiard was released after posting $10,000 bail.

DRUG ARREST, 11:43 p.m. Oct. 25. Alyssa M. Schmidt, 18, of Wayne, was arrested and charged with possession of marijuana and possession of drug paraphernalia during Officer George Pilesky’s investigation of a suspicious vehicle on Chestnut Street at “D” Street. Schmidt was released on her own recognizance.

THEFT, 4:49 p.m. Nov. 2. A resident of Watchung Terrace Senior Housing reported the theft of jewelry items from her apartment. An investigation revealed no signs of forced entry to the apartment and no indications that any unauthorized persons were in the residence. The value of the items taken was reported as $2,700. Officer James Dolinski investigated.

MILLTOWN

BURGLARY, 6:15 p.m. Nov. 17. Milltown Police are investigating a residential burglary which occurred on Benhardt Road. Residents are encouraged to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities and vehicles at any time.

PLAINSBORO

DWI, 2:27 a.m. Nov. 9. A 2008 Ford Edge was stopped on Route 1 north for speeding 77 mph in a 55 mph zone and for failing to maintain a lane of travel. During the traffic stop, the driver, Don Migliorisi, 35, of South Bound Brook, was found to be driving while intoxicated. Migliorisi was arrested and charged with DWI. He was transported to police headquarters for processing. Migliorisi also was issued traffic summonses for reckless driving, speeding and failure to maintain lane. Migliorisi was later released on his own recognizance pending a court date.

HINDERING/ OBSTRUCTION ARREST, 8:54 p.m. Nov. 11. A 2001, four-door black Nissan Maxima was stopped for failing to maintain a lane of travel on Route 1 north. During the motor vehicle stop, the passenger, Hason Cox, 31, of New Brunswick, provided a false name in order to prevent his apprehension. The investigation revealed Cox had two active criminal warrants totaling $3,701 out of New Brunswick and North Brunswick. Cox was arrested and charged with hindering his own apprehension and obstruction of justice with a bail amount of $2,500. Cox was later transported to the Middlesex County Adult Corrections Center in North Brunswick in lieu $6,201 bail and issued a court date.

SAYREVILLE

Sayreville residents are being warned to be wary of fraudulent telephone calls from people posing as Internal Revenue Service representatives. The Sayreville Police Department has seen a spike in IRS phone scams in the past few weeks, in which callers claim that an arrest warrant has been issued by the IRS for unpaid or delinquent taxes and that unless a fine is paid immediately, the victim will be arrested or face legal action.

“A call from someone posing as an IRS agent demanding money and threatening legal action is going to cause some panic. Scams of this nature have been occurring in every part of this country, and we urge our residents not to be deceived by these threatening phone calls,” Sayreville Police Chief John Zebrowski said.

As with most scams, the con-artists are trying to scare the victim into ‘wiring’ money or trying to get a hold of personal information, such as a Social Security or credit card number, authorities said.

The IRS will always send written notification of any tax due via the U.S. mail, authorities said. The IRS never asks for a credit card, debit card or prepaid card information over the phone or insists that taxpayers use a specific payment method to pay tax obligations. The IRS will not take enforcement action immediately following a phone conversation. Taxpayers usually receive prior notification of IRS enforcement action involving IRS tax liens or levies.

Potential phone scam victims may be told that they owe money that must be paid immediately to the IRS or they are entitled to big refunds. When unsuccessful the first time, sometimes phone scammers call back trying a new strategy.

If you get a phone call from someone claiming to be from the IRS and you know you owe taxes or you think you might owe taxes, call the IRS at 1-800-829-1040. The IRS employees at that line can help you with a payment issue, if there really is such an issue. If you know you don’t owe taxes or have no reason to think that you owe any taxes call and report the incident to the Treasury Inspector General Tax Administration at 1-800-366-4484.

If you’ve been targeted by this scam, you should also contact the Federal Trade Commission and use their “FTC Complaint Assistant” at www.ftc.gov. Add “IRS Telephone Scam” to the comments of your complaint.

SOUTH BRUNSWICK

THEFT, 5:40 p.m. Nov. 18. Police are investigating a theft from the donation box at the Islamic Society of Central Jersey on Route 1 Tuesday evening. Police responded to the mosque after staff realized someone had broken open the donation box in the hallway and removed the cash inside.

Police said the theft took place between 5:40 p.m. and 6:30 p.m. while prayer services were being held. The man is described as a white, heavy set with a beard wearing a black jacket, black hat and flip flops. Investigators are examining video footage from around the mosque. Anyone with information is asked to call South Brunswick Police at 732-329-4646.

Source: Central Jersey police departments

Residents are encouraged to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activities and vehicles at any time.
Cox was arrested and charged with hindering his own apprehension and obstruction of justice with a bail amount of $2,500.
Vincent J. Cucchiaro, 24, of Middlesex, was arrested and charged with possession of drug paraphernalia.
